item.title: PHP Error: Column count doesn't match value count at row 1
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

Kimber:

Lol, legit you missed the )") at the end of the VALUES, but I used the code and it worked thanks… Now on the PHPmyadmin once ive FULLY filled out the form all that comes out is:

Ahh yes, I forgot the " inbetween the two parenthesis. I fail.

@Kimber wrote:

Lol, legit you missed the )") at the end of the VALUES, but I used the code and it worked thanks… Now on the PHPmyadmin once ive FULLY filled out the form all that comes out is:

1 firstname lastname address town county postcode phone email howhearaboutus bankname bankname2 bankname3 c c c residentstat creditors estdebts c prevmort mortgageef housemoves i accident NULL

item.title: PHP Error: Column count doesn't match value count at row 1
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

[quote=“OnlyOneRule, post:6, topic:131469”][quote author=xxlegitxx link=topic=182162.msg1660811#msg1660811 date=1186606806]
Night’s right. Try this:

mysql_query("INSERT INTO clients2 (clientid, firstname, lastname, address, town, county, postcode, phone, email, howhearaboutus, bankname, bankname2, bankname3, card1, card2, card3, residentstat, creditors, estdebts, councilt, prevmort, mortgageef, housemoves, injury, accident) 
VALUES('', 'firstname', 'lastname', 'address', 'town', 'county', 'postcode', 'phone', 'email', 'howhearaboutus', 'bankname', 'bankname2', 'bankname3', 'card1', 'card2', 'card3', 'residentstat', 'creditors', 'estdebts', 'councilt', 'prevmort', 'mortgageef', 'housemoves', 'injury', 'accident')) or die(mysql_error());

[/quote]

lol damn, i said that first :mad:

heres what an insert query should look like…

[php]mysql_query(“INSERT INTO table (feild1, feild2, feild3) VALUES (‘input1’, ‘input2’, ‘input3’)”) or die(mysql_error());[/php][/quote]

not neccesarily, you can do it like this aswell:

[php]$mysqli->prepare(“INSERT INTO table SET val1=? AND val2=?”);//using mysqli, its ftw[/php]

Read full topic

mysql_query("INSERT INTO clients2 (clientid, firstname, lastname, address, town, county, postcode, phone, email, howhearaboutus, bankname, bankname2, bankname3, card1, card2, card3, residentstat, creditors, estdebts, councilt, prevmort, mortgageef, housemoves, injury, accident) VALUES('', 'firstname', 'lastname', 'address', 'town', 'county', 'postcode', 'phone', 'email', 'howhearaboutus', 'bankname', 'bankname2', 'bankname3', 'card1', 'card2', 'card3', 'residentstat', 'creditors', 'estdebts', 'councilt', 'prevmort', 'mortgageef', 'housemoves', 'injury', 'accident')) or die(mysql_error()); [/quote]

lol damn, i said that first :mad:

heres what an insert query should look like…

[php]mysql_query(“INSERT INTO table (feild1, feild2, feild3) VALUES (‘input1’, ‘input2’, ‘input3’)”) or die(mysql_error());[/php]

If you have it at auto_increment, you shouldn’t need to specify the key.

item.title: PHP Error: Column count doesn't match value count at row 1
item.dc:creator: @Kimber Kimber
item.description:
@Kimber wrote:

Ive scanned through the code loads, checked up the INSERT INTO and the VALUES and it all looks right

[code]<?php mysql_connect(“localhost”,“admin”,"********") or die(mysql_error());
mysql_select_db(“db”)or die(mysql_error());

$currentdate=date(“YmdHis”);
mysql_query("INSERT INTO clients2 (clientid, firstname, lastname, address, town, county, postcode, phone, email, howhearaboutus, bankname, bankname2, bankname3, card1, card2, card3, residentstat, creditors, estdebts, councilt, prevmort, mortgageef, housemoves, injury, accident)

			VALUES(''),
			('firstname'),
			('lastname'),
			('address'),
			('town'),
			('county'),
            ('postcode'),
            ('phone'),
			('email'),
            ('howhearaboutus'),
            ('bankname'),
			('bankname2'),
			('bankname3'),
			('card1'),
			('card2'),
			('card3'),
			('residentstat'),
			('creditors'),
			('estdebts'),
			('councilt'),
			('prevmort'),
			('mortgageef'),
			('housemoves'),
			('injury'),
            ('accident')")
				   
				  or die(mysql_error());

?>[/code]
